briefing.opening: Hello everyone. I will now begin the climate briefing for January 22, 2026.

sections.title: ğŸ”´ Deepening Climate Crisis and Global Impacts
sections.content: Today, severe impacts due to climate change have been reported in various parts of the world. In Indonesia, massive floods occurred due to climate change and uncontrolled development [1], and in Australia, analysis results indicate that the extreme heatwave and wildfire risk that occurred in early January were 5 times more likely to happen due to human-induced climate change [49, 56, 61, 68, 69, 71, 74, 76]. In the U.S. state of Georgia and across North America, severe winter storms and Arctic cold waves have occurred, leading to active discussions about their connection to climate change [42, 47, 58, 67], and ecological changes, such as the earlier breeding season for Antarctic penguins, are also being observed [45, 52]. Warnings have also been raised that this acceleration of climate change could expose over a billion people to food crises by 2100 [55].

sections.title: ğŸ‡°ğŸ‡· Domestic Climate Change Response and Carbon Neutrality Efforts
sections.content: Domestically, various efforts are continuing to respond to climate change and achieve carbon neutrality. The Korea Climate Change Research Institute hosted a special lecture for opinion leaders on the theme of 'Achieving Carbon Neutrality and the Role of Regions' [3, 5], and the Agriculture, Fisheries, and Maritime Affairs Committee of the Chungnam Provincial Council called for strengthened climate change response and support for agricultural and fishing communities [4, 10, 13]. In the corporate sector, CESCO held an insight seminar to proactively respond to evolving environmental hygiene in the era of climate change [2, 11], and ABB demonstrated its ESG leadership by simultaneously achieving A ratings in the 'Climate Change and Water Security' categories of the CDP assessment [9]. Furthermore, examples of carbon neutrality practices through community and citizen participation, such as Jecheon City's workshop on corporate response strategies for carbon neutrality [15] and Bucheon City's food waste reduction carbon neutrality campaign [18, 19], are also gaining attention.

sections.title: ğŸŒ± Accelerating Renewable Energy Transition and Current Challenges
sections.content: Amidst efforts to accelerate the transition to renewable energy, several challenges have also emerged. Korea Southern Power (KOSPO) has shown positive developments, announcing strengthened technological innovation and strategic investment in the renewable energy sector and building AI training data for wind and solar power facilities [22, 29, 30], and the Korea Power Exchange (KPX) plans to operate the 'Renewable Energy Quasi-Central Dispatch Operating System' starting this spring and expand remote control incentives [25, 37]. However, arguments have been raised that the construction of new LNG power plants conflicts with carbon neutrality goals [16, 20], and controversy has arisen regarding whether air-source heat pumps qualify as renewable energy [27]. Furthermore, Musk, attending the Davos Forum, mentioned that U.S. tariffs are posing a challenge to solar power generation [79], and the special provisions for renewable energy in the Gwangju-Jeonnam Integration Special Act have emerged as a 'hot potato' [32], indicating a need for continuous discussion on policy consensus and technical definitions.

sections.title: ğŸŒ International Community's Perception and Response to Climate Change
sections.content: In the international community, perceptions of climate change appear mixed. At the Davos Forum, there were observations that climate change discussions were sidelined from the main agenda [41], and reports that the Trump administration deleted climate change information from Fort Sumter [48, 57] raise concerns that certain political trends could set back climate change response efforts. Meanwhile, Americans tended to perceive that climate change would cause greater harm globally than to individuals [43], and Greenland was highlighted as playing a very important role in climate change science [40]. Furthermore, various levels of response efforts are continuing, such as the announcement of new global guidelines to protect workers from health and safety risks related to climate change [70].

briefing.closing: As we have reviewed in today's briefing, climate change is having severe impacts globally, and both domestic and international response efforts and challenges coexist. This concludes today's climate briefing.
